def generateHamiltonian(self, modelType, closed=False): 
182    def generateHamiltonian(self, modelType, closed = False):
183        """Helper Function to generate Hamiltonians.
184        
185        From the model type, generates the Hamiltonian Pauli Strings
186
187        Args: 
188            modelType (Tuple of Strings): See previous documentation
189            closed (bool): 
190                True if the model is period.
191
192        """
193        hamiltonian = []
194
195        if modelType == "xx": #XXII + IXXI + IIXX
196            for i in range(self.sites - 1):
197                term = ((0,) * i) + ((1,) * 2) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2 - i))
198                hamiltonian.append(term)
199            if  closed:
200                term = (1,) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2)) + (1,)
201                hamiltonian.append(term)
202
203            
204            
205        elif modelType == "yy": #YYII + IYYI + IIYY
206            for i in range(self.sites - 1):
207                term = ((0,) * i) + ((2,) * 2) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2 - i))
208                hamiltonian.append(term)
209            if  closed:
210                term = (2,) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2)) + (2,)
211                hamiltonian.append(term)
212
213            
214            
215        elif modelType == "zz": #ZZII + IZZI + IIZZ
216            for i in range(self.sites - 1):
217                term = ((0,) * i) + ((3,) * 2) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2 - i))
218                hamiltonian.append(term)
219            if  closed:
220                term = (3,) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2)) + (3,)
221                hamiltonian.append(term)
222
223
224        elif modelType == "xy": #XXII + YYII + IXXI + IYYI + IIXX + IIYY
225            for i in range(self.sites - 1):
226                termX = ((0,) * i) + ((1,) * 2) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2 - i))
227                termY = ((0,) * i) + ((2,) * 2) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2 - i))
228                hamiltonian.append(termX)
229                hamiltonian.append(termY)
230            if  closed:
231                termX = (1,) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2)) + (1,)
232                termY = (2,) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2)) + (2,)
233                hamiltonian.append(termX)
234                hamiltonian.append(termY)
235
236            
237        elif modelType == "kitaev_even": #XXII + IYYI + IIXX
238            for i in range(self.sites - 1):
239                if i % 2 == 0:
240                    term = ((0,) * i) + ((1,) * 2) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2 - i))
241                else:
242                    term = ((0,) * i) + ((2,) * 2) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2 - i))
243                hamiltonian.append(term)
244            if  closed:
245                term = (2,) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2)) + (2,)
246                hamiltonian.append(term)
247
248            
249            
250        elif modelType == "kitaev_odd": #YYII + IXXI + IIYY
251            for i in range(self.sites - 1):
252                if i % 2 == 0:
253                    term = ((0,) * i) + ((2,) * 2) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2 - i))
254                else:
255                    term = ((0,) * i) + ((1,) * 2) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2 - i))
256                hamiltonian.append(term)
257            if  closed:
258                term = (1,) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2)) + (1,)
259                hamiltonian.append(term)
260
261
262
263        elif modelType == "heisenberg": #XXII + YYII + ZZII + ...
264            for i in range(self.sites - 1):
265                termX = ((0,) * i) + ((1,) * 2) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2 - i))
266                termY = ((0,) * i) + ((2,) * 2) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2 - i))
267                termZ = ((0,) * i) + ((3,) * 2) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2 - i))
268                hamiltonian.append(termX)
269                hamiltonian.append(termY)
270                hamiltonian.append(termZ)
271            if  closed:
272                termX = (1,) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2)) + (1,)
273                termY = (2,) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2)) + (2,)
274                termY = (3,) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2)) + (3,)
275                hamiltonian.append(termX)
276                hamiltonian.append(termY)
277                hamiltonian.append(termZ)
278
279            
280
281        elif modelType == "tfim": # ZZII + IZZI + IIXZZ + XIII + IXII + IIXI + IIIX
282            #raise Exception("Warning: TransverseIsing Involution not yet implemented, so m construction will fail")
283            for i in range(self.sites - 1):
284                term = ((0,) * i) + (3,3) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2 - i))
285                hamiltonian.append(term)
286            if  closed:
287                term = (3,) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 2)) + (3,)
288                hamiltonian.append(term)
289            for i in range(self.sites):
290                term = ((0,) * i) + (1,) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 1 - i))
291                hamiltonian.append(term)
292
293        elif modelType == 'tfxy':
294            for i in range(self.sites):
295                term = (0,)*i + (3,) + (0,)*(self.sites-i-1) 
296                hamiltonian.append(term)
297            
298            for i in range(self.sites-1):
299                term = (0,)*i + (1,1) + (0,)*(self.sites-i-2) 
300                hamiltonian.append(term)
301                term = (0,)*i + (2,2) + (0,)*(self.sites-i-2) 
302                hamiltonian.append(term)
303                
304            if closed:
305                term = (1,) + (0,)*(self.sites-2) + (1,)
306                hamiltonian.append(term)
307                term = (2,) + (0,)*(self.sites-2) + (2,)
308                hamiltonian.append(term)
309            
310
311        elif modelType == "transverse_z": # ZIII + IZII + IIZI + IIIZ
312            for i in range(self.sites):
313                term = ((0,) * i) + (3,) + ((0,) * (self.sites - 1 - i))
314                hamiltonian.append(term)
315
316        else:
317            raise Exception("Invalid Model. Valid models include: 'XX', 'YY', 'ZZ', 'XY', 'KitaevEven', 'KitaevOdd', 'Heisenberg', TransverseIsing', and 'Transverse_Z'")
318        return hamiltonian

def getHamiltonian(self, type='tuples'): 
320    def getHamiltonian(self, type='tuples'):
321        """ Based on the type, returns the Hamiltonian from the object and formats it.
322        Args:
323            type (String, default = 'tuples'): Specifies the return type of the function.
324                Valid inputs:
325
326                 - 'tuples': Return formatted as `[(coefficient, (PauliString), ... ]`
327
328                 - 'printTuples': Prints out to the console ``(coefficient, (PauliString)) \n ...``
329
330                 - 'printText': Prints out ``'coefficient * 'PauliString' + ....``
331
332                 - 'text': Return formatted as a list of `[[coefficient, 'PauliString']]`
333        
334        Returns:
335            For type=`'tuples'` or type=`'text'`, returns
336
337            - `'tuples'`: A list of Coefficient, (PauliString) Tuple pairs
338            - `'text'`: A List of Coefficient 'PauliString' List pairs
339        
340        Raises:
341            ValueError: Invalid type
342        """
343        if type == 'tuples':
344            returnVal = []
345            for (co, tup) in zip(self.HCoefs, self.HTuples):
346                returnVal.append((co,tup))
347            return returnVal
348        elif type == 'printTuples':
349            for (co, tup) in zip(self.HCoefs, self.HTuples):
350                print((co,tup))
351        elif type == 'printText':
352            for (co, tup) in zip(self.HCoefs, self.HTuples):
353                print(str(co) + " * " + str(paulilabel(tup))) #Prints coefficient'pauliString'
354        elif type == 'text':
355            returnlist = []
356            for (co, tup) in zip(self.HCoefs, self.HTuples):
357                returnlist.append([co,  str(paulilabel(tup))]) #Prints coefficient'pauliString'
358            return returnlist
359        else:
360            raise ValueError('Invalid Type: Must be "tuples", "printTuples", "printText", or "text"')

class Cartan: 
362class Cartan:
363    """
364    Class to contain the options for performing Cartan Decomposition on a Hamiltonian
365        
366    # Object containing the functions and data required to generate a Cartan Decomposition from a given Hamiltonian. 
367    from object_based.PauliOps import commutatePauliString
368
369    TODO:
370    * Add in k simplification functions
371
372    Authors:
373    * Thomas Steckmann
374    * Efekan Kokcu
375
376    Functionality:
377    * Generate Hamiltonian Algebra
378    * Generate k, m, h partition
379    * Choose involution (Default - Even/Odd)
380    * Seed choice of h
381    * Modify k (Additional Decomposition, TODO: Abelian Decomposition, Piling)
382    """
383    def __init__(self, hamObj, involution='evenOdd', order = 0, manualMode=0):
384        """ Generates the Cartan Object
385        
386        Args:
387            hamObj (Hamiltonian): Passes a Hamiltonian Object containing the full information about the system
388            involution (String, default='evenOdd'):
389                Allows a choice of the k,m involution
390
391                Options:
392                * `'evenOdd'`: m contains an even number of non-identity pauli terms in each string, k contains an odd number of non-identity elements
393                * `'knejaGlaser'`: m contains elements ending in Y or X, k contains elements ending in I or Z
394                * `'count' + 'X', 'Y', or 'Z'`: Counts of the number of the specified Pauli Tuple. Even count in m, odd in k
395            order (int, default = 0):
396                g(H) is generated iteratively until it fails to generate new terms. We call each term in H, [H,H], [H,[H,H]], ... order 0, 1, 2, and going up.
397                Generally, the larger the system the larger the order of terms required to generate g(H). Setting the order greater than 0 ensure that g(H) will only result in terms the distance of commutators from H.
398                However, this results in an incomplete algebra for g. Be warned. 
399            manualMode (bool, default = 0):
400                Choose either 0 (automatic) or 1 (manual). automatic generates h, k, m, and h when the object is created. manual requires the user call the respective functions.
401        Attributes:
402            hamiltonian (::hamiltonian:: object): Allows access to HCoefficients and HTuples
403            HTuples (List of Tuples): Copies over the HTuples from the hamiltonian object
404            g (List of Tuples): Generates formatted like k + h + (m without h)
405            k (List of Tuples): Specified by the decomposition. Changing k regenerates h and the order of g (g = k + h + (m\h))
406            h (List of Tuples): Specified by SubAlgebra(). Defaults to seeding by m, otherwise allows for inclusion of specific elements
407        """
408        self.mode = manualMode
409        self.hamiltonian = hamObj
410        self.HTuples = self.hamiltonian.HTuples
411        if self.mode == 0:
412            self.g = self.makeGroup(self.HTuples, order)
413            self.decompose(involution)
414        
415
416    def decompose(self, involutionName):
417        """
418        Sets a new Involution using a switch. Regenerates h using the default first element in m
419
420        Options:
421                * `'evenOdd'`: m contains an even number of non-identity pauli terms in each string, k contains an odd nunber of non-idenity elements
422                * `'knejaGlaser'`: m contains elements ending in Y or X, k contains elements ending in I or Z
423                * `'count' + 'X', 'Y', or 'Z'`: Counts of the number of the specified Pauli Tuple. Even count in m, odd in k
424        """
425        self.involution = involutionName #Store involution name
426
427        if involutionName == 'evenOdd': 
428            (self.m, self.k) = self.evenOdd(self.g)
429        elif involutionName == 'knejaGlaser':
430            (self.m, self.k) = self.knejaGlaser(self.g)
431        elif involutionName == 'countX':
432            (self.m, self.k) = self.elemcount(self.g, 1)
433        elif involutionName == 'countY':
434            (self.m, self.k) = self.elemcount(self.g, 2)
435        elif involutionName == 'countZ': 
436            (self.m, self.k) = self.elemcount(self.g, 3)
437        invalidInvolutionFlag = 0
438        for Hi in self.HTuples:
439            if not Hi in self.m:
440                invalidInvolutionFlag = 1
441                break
442        if invalidInvolutionFlag == 1:
443            raise Exception('Invalid Involution. Please Choose an involution such that H ‚äÇ m')
444        if self.mode == 0:
445            self.subAlgebra()
446
447    def makeGroup(self,g, order=0):
448        '''
449        Returns a closure of a given list of pauli strings (g). The list doesn't include any coefficients, it is just
450        a tuple like (0,2,3) representing IYZ.
451
452        Args:
453            g (List of Tuples):
454                A set of Pauli Strings
455            order (int, default = 0): 
456                The number of terms to include in g. If order = 0, generates the full g(H). 0th order is H, 1st is [H,H], and 2nd is [H,[H,H]], etc
457
458
459        Returns:
460            List of Tuples: ùñå(H), the Hamiltonian Algebra generated by the input g
461        '''
462        if order == 0:
463            flag = 0 
464            while (flag == 0):
465                flag = 1
466                L = len(g) #g initializes as H
467                #initialize commutations
468                coms = [] #Tracks the commutations generated in this iteration
469
470                #calculate all possible commutations 
471                for i in range(L): #First index in the commutator
472                    for j in range(i,L): #Second index is all terms after this in the list
473                        m = commutatePauliString(1,g[i],1,g[j]) #generates the commutation
474                        #add all new ones to the list, if they are not in the list and are not 0
475                        if (abs(m[0])>0) & (self.included(coms,m[1])==0) & (self.included(g,m[1])==0):
476                            #set flag to 0 whenever there is a new term to be added. If the flag remains 1, the loop terminates
477                            flag = 0
478                            coms.append(m[1])
479
480                #then merge initial list with these new commutations
481                g = g + coms
482            return g
483        else:
484            loopOrder = 0
485            flag = 0 
486            while (flag == 0 and loopOrder <= order):
487                flag = 1
488                L = len(g) #g initializes as H
489                #initialize commutations
490                coms = [] #Tracks the commutations generated in this iteration
491
492                #calculate all possible commutations 
493                for i in range(L): #First index in the commutator
494                    for j in range(i,L): #Second index is all terms after this in the list
495                        m = commutatePauliString(1,g[i],1,g[j]) #generates the commutation
496                        #add all new ones to the list, if they are not in the list and are not 0
497                        if (abs(m[0])>0) & (self.included(coms,m[1])==0) & (self.included(g,m[1])==0):
498                            #set flag to 0 whenever there is a new term to be added. If the flag remains 1, the loop terminates
499                            flag = 0
500                            coms.append(m[1])
501
502                #then merge initial list with these new commutations
503                loopOrder += 1
504                g = g + coms
505            return g
506
507    
508    def elemcount(self,g,element):
509        '''
510        Counts the number of given elements (X,Y or Z in number), and puts even numbers in m, odd numbers in k. 
511        For element=2, it corresponds to Œ∏(g) = -g^T
512        '''    
513        k = []
514        m = []
515        
516        for i in range(len(g)):
517            elem = g[i]
518            count = 0
519            for j in range(len(elem)):
520                if elem[j] == element:
521                    count=count+1
522            if count%2 == 0:
523                m.append(elem)
524            else:
525                k.append(elem)
526            
527        return m,k
528    
529    def included(self,g,m):
530        '''Following function returns 0 if tuple m is not incu=luded in tuple list g, returns 1 if it is included.
531            
532            Args:
533                g (List of Tuples): 
534                    The List of Pauli string elements in the Hamiltonian Algebra ùñå(H)
535                m (Tuple of 0,1,2,3):
536                    Pauli string in the set ùñí
537
538            Returns: 
539                1 if m is in g
540                0 if not
541        '''
542        L = len(g)
543        res = 0    
544        for i in range(L):
545            if g[i]==m:
546                res = 1
547                break
548        
549        return res
550

552    def evenOdd(self,g):
553        """ Partitions the Algebra by counting the number of non-idenity Pauli elements
554
555        Args:
556            g (List of Tuples):
557                The Algebra to partition
558        
559        Returns:
560            k (List of Tuples):
561                The List of Pauli Strings with Odd non-identity terms
562            m (List of Tuples):
563                The List of Pauli Strings with Even non-idenity terms
564        """
565        k = []
566        m = []
567        
568        for i in range(len(g)):
569            elem = g[i]
570            count = 0
571            for j in range(len(elem)):
572                if elem[j] > 0:
573                    count=count+1
574            if count%2 == 0:
575                m.append(elem)
576            else:
577                k.append(elem)
578                
579        return m,k
580
581    def knejaGlaser(self,g):
582        '''
583        Following one is the Kneja Glaser decomposition. 
584        It corresponds to \theta(g) = III...IZ g III..IZ
585        ''' 
586        k = []
587        m = []
588        
589        for i in range(len(g)):
590            elem = g[i]
591            last = elem[len(elem)-1]
592            if  (last == 3) | (last == 0):
593                k.append(elem)
594            else:
595                m.append(elem)
596            
597        return m,k
598
599    def subAlgebra(self,seedList=None):

636                    m_tuples.pop(index)
637                    break

639                index = index + 1

Object containing the functions and data required to generate a Cartan Decomposition from a given Hamiltonian.

Cartan(hamObj, involution='evenOdd', order=0, manualMode=0) 
383    def __init__(self, hamObj, involution='evenOdd', order = 0, manualMode=0):
384        """ Generates the Cartan Object
385        
386        Args:
387            hamObj (Hamiltonian): Passes a Hamiltonian Object containing the full information about the system
388            involution (String, default='evenOdd'):
389                Allows a choice of the k,m involution
390
391                Options:
392                * `'evenOdd'`: m contains an even number of non-identity pauli terms in each string, k contains an odd number of non-identity elements
393                * `'knejaGlaser'`: m contains elements ending in Y or X, k contains elements ending in I or Z
394                * `'count' + 'X', 'Y', or 'Z'`: Counts of the number of the specified Pauli Tuple. Even count in m, odd in k
395            order (int, default = 0):
396                g(H) is generated iteratively until it fails to generate new terms. We call each term in H, [H,H], [H,[H,H]], ... order 0, 1, 2, and going up.
397                Generally, the larger the system the larger the order of terms required to generate g(H). Setting the order greater than 0 ensure that g(H) will only result in terms the distance of commutators from H.
398                However, this results in an incomplete algebra for g. Be warned. 
399            manualMode (bool, default = 0):
400                Choose either 0 (automatic) or 1 (manual). automatic generates h, k, m, and h when the object is created. manual requires the user call the respective functions.
401        Attributes:
402            hamiltonian (::hamiltonian:: object): Allows access to HCoefficients and HTuples
403            HTuples (List of Tuples): Copies over the HTuples from the hamiltonian object
404            g (List of Tuples): Generates formatted like k + h + (m without h)
405            k (List of Tuples): Specified by the decomposition. Changing k regenerates h and the order of g (g = k + h + (m\h))
406            h (List of Tuples): Specified by SubAlgebra(). Defaults to seeding by m, otherwise allows for inclusion of specific elements
407        """
408        self.mode = manualMode
409        self.hamiltonian = hamObj
410        self.HTuples = self.hamiltonian.HTuples
411        if self.mode == 0:
412            self.g = self.makeGroup(self.HTuples, order)
413            self.decompose(involution)

Generates the Cartan Object

Args
  • hamObj (Hamiltonian): Passes a Hamiltonian Object containing the full information about the system

  • involution (String, default='evenOdd'): Allows a choice of the k,m involution

    Options:

    • 'evenOdd': m contains an even number of non-identity pauli terms in each string, k contains an odd number of non-identity elements
    • 'knejaGlaser': m contains elements ending in Y or X, k contains elements ending in I or Z
    • 'count' + 'X', 'Y', or 'Z': Counts of the number of the specified Pauli Tuple. Even count in m, odd in k
  • order (int, default = 0): g(H) is generated iteratively until it fails to generate new terms. We call each term in H, [H,H], [H,[H,H]], ... order 0, 1, 2, and going up. Generally, the larger the system the larger the order of terms required to generate g(H). Setting the order greater than 0 ensure that g(H) will only result in terms the distance of commutators from H. However, this results in an incomplete algebra for g. Be warned.
  • manualMode (bool, default = 0): Choose either 0 (automatic) or 1 (manual). automatic generates h, k, m, and h when the object is created. manual requires the user call the respective functions.
Attributes
  • hamiltonian (: :hamiltonian:: object): Allows access to HCoefficients and HTuples
  • HTuples (List of Tuples): Copies over the HTuples from the hamiltonian object
  • g (List of Tuples): Generates formatted like k + h + (m without h)
  • k (List of Tuples): Specified by the decomposition. Changing k regenerates h and the order of g (g = k + h + (m\h))
  • h (List of Tuples): Specified by SubAlgebra(). Defaults to seeding by m, otherwise allows for inclusion of specific elements
def decompose(self, involutionName): 
416    def decompose(self, involutionName):
417        """
418        Sets a new Involution using a switch. Regenerates h using the default first element in m
419
420        Options:
421                * `'evenOdd'`: m contains an even number of non-identity pauli terms in each string, k contains an odd nunber of non-idenity elements
422                * `'knejaGlaser'`: m contains elements ending in Y or X, k contains elements ending in I or Z
423                * `'count' + 'X', 'Y', or 'Z'`: Counts of the number of the specified Pauli Tuple. Even count in m, odd in k
424        """
425        self.involution = involutionName #Store involution name
426
427        if involutionName == 'evenOdd': 
428            (self.m, self.k) = self.evenOdd(self.g)
429        elif involutionName == 'knejaGlaser':
430            (self.m, self.k) = self.knejaGlaser(self.g)
431        elif involutionName == 'countX':
432            (self.m, self.k) = self.elemcount(self.g, 1)
433        elif involutionName == 'countY':
434            (self.m, self.k) = self.elemcount(self.g, 2)
435        elif involutionName == 'countZ': 
436            (self.m, self.k) = self.elemcount(self.g, 3)
437        invalidInvolutionFlag = 0
438        for Hi in self.HTuples:
439            if not Hi in self.m:
440                invalidInvolutionFlag = 1
441                break
442        if invalidInvolutionFlag == 1:
443            raise Exception('Invalid Involution. Please Choose an involution such that H ‚äÇ m')
444        if self.mode == 0:
445            self.subAlgebra()

def makeGroup(self, g, order=0): 
447    def makeGroup(self,g, order=0):
448        '''
449        Returns a closure of a given list of pauli strings (g). The list doesn't include any coefficients, it is just
450        a tuple like (0,2,3) representing IYZ.
451
452        Args:
453            g (List of Tuples):
454                A set of Pauli Strings
455            order (int, default = 0): 
456                The number of terms to include in g. If order = 0, generates the full g(H). 0th order is H, 1st is [H,H], and 2nd is [H,[H,H]], etc
457
458
459        Returns:
460            List of Tuples: ùñå(H), the Hamiltonian Algebra generated by the input g
461        '''
462        if order == 0:
463            flag = 0 
464            while (flag == 0):
465                flag = 1
466                L = len(g) #g initializes as H
467                #initialize commutations
468                coms = [] #Tracks the commutations generated in this iteration
469
470                #calculate all possible commutations 
471                for i in range(L): #First index in the commutator
472                    for j in range(i,L): #Second index is all terms after this in the list
473                        m = commutatePauliString(1,g[i],1,g[j]) #generates the commutation
474                        #add all new ones to the list, if they are not in the list and are not 0
475                        if (abs(m[0])>0) & (self.included(coms,m[1])==0) & (self.included(g,m[1])==0):
476                            #set flag to 0 whenever there is a new term to be added. If the flag remains 1, the loop terminates
477                            flag = 0
478                            coms.append(m[1])
479
480                #then merge initial list with these new commutations
481                g = g + coms
482            return g
483        else:
484            loopOrder = 0
485            flag = 0 
486            while (flag == 0 and loopOrder <= order):
487                flag = 1
488                L = len(g) #g initializes as H
489                #initialize commutations
490                coms = [] #Tracks the commutations generated in this iteration
491
492                #calculate all possible commutations 
493                for i in range(L): #First index in the commutator
494                    for j in range(i,L): #Second index is all terms after this in the list
495                        m = commutatePauliString(1,g[i],1,g[j]) #generates the commutation
496                        #add all new ones to the list, if they are not in the list and are not 0
497                        if (abs(m[0])>0) & (self.included(coms,m[1])==0) & (self.included(g,m[1])==0):
498                            #set flag to 0 whenever there is a new term to be added. If the flag remains 1, the loop terminates
499                            flag = 0
500                            coms.append(m[1])
501
502                #then merge initial list with these new commutations
503                loopOrder += 1
504                g = g + coms
505            return g

Returns a closure of a given list of pauli strings (g). The list doesn't include any coefficients, it is just a tuple like (0,2,3) representing IYZ.

Args
  • g (List of Tuples): A set of Pauli Strings
  • order (int, default = 0): The number of terms to include in g. If order = 0, generates the full g(H). 0th order is H, 1st is [H,H], and 2nd is [H,[H,H]], etc
Returns

List of Tuples: ùñå(H), the Hamiltonian Algebra generated by the input g

def elemcount(self, g, element): 
508    def elemcount(self,g,element):
509        '''
510        Counts the number of given elements (X,Y or Z in number), and puts even numbers in m, odd numbers in k. 
511        For element=2, it corresponds to Œ∏(g) = -g^T
512        '''    
513        k = []
514        m = []
515        
516        for i in range(len(g)):
517            elem = g[i]
518            count = 0
519            for j in range(len(elem)):
520                if elem[j] == element:
521                    count=count+1
522            if count%2 == 0:
523                m.append(elem)
524            else:
525                k.append(elem)
526            
527        return m,k

536                    Pauli string in the set ùñí
537

541        '''

def evenOdd(self, g): 
552    def evenOdd(self,g):
553        """ Partitions the Algebra by counting the number of non-idenity Pauli elements
554

557                The Algebra to partition
558        
559        Returns:

561                The List of Pauli Strings with Odd non-identity terms

563                The List of Pauli Strings with Even non-idenity terms

573                    count=count+1

def knejaGlaser(self, g): 
581    def knejaGlaser(self,g):
582        '''
583        Following one is the Kneja Glaser decomposition. 
584        It corresponds to \theta(g) = III...IZ g III..IZ
585        ''' 
586        k = []
587        m = []
588        
589        for i in range(len(g)):
590            elem = g[i]
591            last = elem[len(elem)-1]
592            if  (last == 3) | (last == 0):
593                k.append(elem)
594            else:
595                m.append(elem)
596            
597        return m,k

class FindParameters: 
 642class FindParameters:
 643    """
 644    From a Cartan Decomposition, runs the optimizer to find the appropriate parameters for a circuit
 645
 646    Warning: Very long runtime for more than 8ish qubits
 647
 648    Authors:
 649    * Thomas Steckmann
 650    * Efekan Kokcu
 651    """
 652    def __init__(self, cartan, saveFileName = None, loadfileName=None, optimizerMethod='BFGS', accuracy=1e-5, initialGuess=None, steps = 5000, useCommTables=True):
 653        """
 654        Initializing a FindParameters class automatically runs the optimizer over the Cartan decomposition and provided Hamiltonian
 655        
 656        If saveFileName is provided, verifies file location before proceeding, and saves the output as a csv
 657        If loadFileName is provided, does not run the optimizer and instead reads data from the provided file
 658
 659        TODO:
 660            * Write Load file functions
 661        
 662        Args:
 663            cartan (Obj Cartan): The Cartan object containing the k,h, and Hamiltonian information
 664            saveFileName (String, default=None): path to save the output. Do not include an extension ('csv' or 'txt')
 665            loadFileName (String, default=None): path to a csv containing previous optimizer results. Do not add .csv or .txt
 666            optimizer (String, default='BFGS'): The Scipy optimizer to use. Easy to add new ones, but must be done manually
 667                
 668                Options: 
 669                    * `'BFGS'` : Uses Gradient
 670                    * `'Powel'`: Does not use Gradient
 671            accuracy (float, default=1e-5): Optimizer convergence Criteria
 672            initialGuess (List of values): Allows the user to specify the inital guess for k. Must be correct, no input checking is currently implemented
 673            steps (int): The maximum number of optimization steps before termination
 674        
 675        Returns:
 676            * Progress updates and runtime predictions
 677            * prints the results of the optimization
 678        """
 679        #Initialize Values
 680        self.cartan = cartan #Extracts the hamiltonian object
 681        self.hamiltonian = self.cartan.hamiltonian #Extracts the hamiltonain objects
 682        self.useCommTables = useCommTables
 683        self.optimizerMethod = optimizerMethod
 684        self.accuracy = accuracy
 685        self.lenK = len(self.cartan.k)
 686        self.lenh = len(self.cartan.h)
 687        self.steps = steps
 688        #Begin Optimizer
 689        if loadfileName is not None: #If able to, loads prior results
 690            #with open(loadfileName + '.csv', "r") as f:
 691            #    csv_reader = csv.reader(csv_file, delimiter=',')
 692            raise Exception('Unable to continue, file loading is not implemented')
 693        elif self.lenK == 0: #Specific exception handling to prevent breaking on commuting Hamiltonians 
 694            self.hCoefs = self.hamiltonian.HCoefs
 695            #self.hTuples = self.hamiltonian.HTuples
 696            self.kCoefs = []
 697        else:   
 698            if saveFileName is not None:
 699                if not os.access(saveFileName, os.W_OK): #Verifies write permission
 700                    raise Exception('Save File location does not have write access. Aborting Optimization.')
 701                self.saveFileName = saveFileName
 702            
 703            #Generating reused values before begining the optimizer loop
 704            if useCommTables == True: #Faster, but only works for a complete algebra
 705                self.setCommutatorTables() #Sets values for a look-up table for the commutators
 706                self.generateIndexLists()
 707            #Generates coefficients for v, a dense element in the h algebra
 708            pi = np.pi
 709            self.vcoefs = [1]
 710            for i in range(len(self.cartan.h)-1):
 711                term = pi*self.vcoefs[i]
 712                while term > 1:
 713                    term = term-1
 714                self.vcoefs.append(term)
 715            
 716
 717            
 718            #If specified, defines an inital guess. If not, sets it to all zeros
 719            if initialGuess is not None:
 720                self.initialGuess = initialGuess
 721            else:
 722                self.initialGuess = initialGuess = np.zeros(len(self.cartan.k))
 723            
 724            #Calls the function that contains the optimizer loop
 725            total_time = time.time()
 726            self.optimizerOutput = self.optimize()
 727            timepassed = time.time() - total_time
 728            print('--- ' + str(timepassed) +  ' seconds ---')
 729
 730            self.sethVecFromk()
 731            self.error = self.errorhVec()
 732
 733            print('Optimization Error:')
 734            print(self.error)
 735
 736            if saveFileName is not None:
 737                self.saveKH()
 738
 739    def setCommutatorTables(self):
 740        """ 
 741        Generates commutator look-up tables for the commutators of different elements
 742
 743        Important: g must be ordered as k + h + (the rest of m). Does not work without this ordering
 744        """
 745        
 746        k_tuples = self.cartan.k.copy()
 747        h_tuples = self.cartan.h.copy()
 748        m_tuples = self.cartan.m.copy()
 749        
 750        index = 0
 751        
 752        while index < len(m_tuples):
 753            flag = 0
 754            for i in range(len(h_tuples)):
 755                if m_tuples[index] == h_tuples[i]:
 756                    flag = 1
 757                    m_tuples.pop(index)
 758                    break
 759            if flag == 0:
 760                index = index + 1
 761        
 762        g_tuples = k_tuples + h_tuples + m_tuples
 763        
 764        self.comm_table = np.zeros((len(g_tuples),len(g_tuples)))
 765        self.comm_coefs = np.zeros((len(g_tuples),len(g_tuples)),dtype=np.complex_)
 766        
 767        for i in range(len(g_tuples)):
 768            for j in range(len(g_tuples)):
 769                res = self.commutatePauliString(1,g_tuples[i],1,g_tuples[j])
 770                
 771                self.comm_coefs[i][j] = res[0]
 772                
 773                if res[0]==0:
 774                    self.comm_table[i][j]=0
 775                else:
 776                    for q in range(len(g_tuples)):
 777                        if res[1] == g_tuples[q]:
 778                            self.comm_table[i][j] = q
 779    
 780    def generateIndexLists(self):
 781        """Generates a lists for H, h, and k using indices in g instead of as lists of Tuples"""
 782
 783        #Computes the indices of each of the k elements in the g list                   
 784        self.kElementIndices = []
 785        for i in range(len(self.cartan.k)):
 786            for j in range(len(self.cartan.g)):
 787                if self.cartan.k[i] == self.cartan.g[j]:
 788                    self.kElementIndices.append(j)
 789                    break  
 790
 791        #computes the indicies of each of the Ham elements in the g list
 792        self.HElementIndices = [] 
 793        Htuples = self.hamiltonian.HTuples
 794        for i in range(len(Htuples)):
 795            for j in range(len(self.cartan.g)):
 796                if self.cartan.g[j]==Htuples[i]:
 797                    self.HElementIndices.append(j)
 798                    break
 799        
 800        #Computes the indices of the of the h elements in the g list:
 801        self.hElementIndices = [] 
 802        htuples = self.cartan.h
 803        for i in range(len(htuples)):
 804            for j in range(len(self.cartan.g)):
 805                if self.cartan.g[j]==htuples[i]:
 806                    self.hElementIndices.append(j)
 807                    break
 808
 809    def optimize(self):
 810        """
 811        Chooses between methods of optimization. Current options are 'BFGS' and 'Powell' from scipy.optimize
 812
 813        Sets the attribute kCoefs, which are the results of the optimizer
 814
 815        Returns: 
 816            The object returned by the Scipy Optimizer. Contains information about the minimum, parameters, and a few other things
 817        """
 818        initialGuess = self.initialGuess
 819        if self.optimizerMethod == 'BFGS':
 820            optimiumReturn = scipy.optimize.minimize(self.CostFunction,initialGuess, method='BFGS', jac = self.gradCostFunction,options={'disp':True, 'gtol':self.accuracy, 'maxiter':self.steps})
 821        elif self.optimizerMethod == 'Powell':
 822            optimiumReturn = scipy.optimize.minimize(self.CostFunction,initialGuess, method='Powell',options={'disp':True, 'ftol':self.accuracy, 'maxiter':self.steps})
 823        self.kCoefs = optimiumReturn.x
 824        return optimiumReturn

 826    def generalCostFunction(self, thetas1, thetas2, index):
 827        '''
 828        This returns Tr(e<sup>i‚Ä¢thetas1‚Ä¢k1</sup>‚Ä¢v‚Ä¢e<sup>-thetas2‚Ä¢k2</sup>‚Ä¢H)
 829        (To make it clear, for Earp and Pachos function, we have k1=k2=k, thetas1=thetas2=thetas)
 830
 831        Args:
 832            thetas1 (List): The coefficients for the k_tuples on the left side
 833            thetas2 (List): The coefficients for the K_tuples on the right side
 834            index (int): The number of k elements acting on v
 835
 836        Returns:
 837            Tr(e<sup>i‚Ä¢thetas1‚Ä¢k1</sup>)‚Ä¢v‚Ä¢e<sup>-thetas2‚Ä¢k2</sup>‚Ä¢H)
 838        
 839        TODO: 
 840            * Comment the steps in this section
 841        '''
 842        if self.useCommTables:
 843            maxsize = 0
 844            #Prepares two lists: One for v matching dense coefficients with indices in g, One for H matching coefficients to indeices
 845            resV = [self.vcoefs,self.hElementIndices]
 846            resH = [self.hamiltonian.HCoefs, self.HElementIndices]
 847
 848            for i in range(len(thetas1)-1,index,-1):
 849                resV = self.adj_action(thetas1[i],self.kElementIndices[i],resV[0],resV[1])
 850
 851            
 852            #add each exp(thetas2*k2) to the list in reverse order and negative coefficients
 853            for i in range(index):
 854                resH = self.adj_action(-thetas2[i],self.kElementIndices[i],resH[0],resH[1])
 855
 856            #create identity matrix for this dimensions
 857            I = (0,)*self.hamiltonian.sites
 858            
 859            
 860            resV = self.multiplyLinCombRound([1],[I],resV[0],resV[1],self.accuracy)  
 861            
 862            if index >= 0:
 863                resV = self.multiplyLinCombRound([math.cos(thetas1[index]),1j*math.sin(thetas1[index])],[I,self.cartan.k[index]],resV[0],resV[1],self.accuracy)    
 864
 865                resV = self.multiplyLinCombRound(resV[0],resV[1],[math.cos(thetas2[index]),-1j*math.sin(thetas2[index])],[I,self.cartan.k[index]],self.accuracy)    
 866
 867                    
 868            #get trace of v*H
 869            trace = 0
 870            for i in range(len(resV[0])):
 871                for j in range(len(resH[0])):
 872                    if resV[1][i] == self.cartan.g[int(resH[1][j])]: #Checks if the elements are the same
 873                        trace = trace + resV[0][i]*resH[0][j]
 874            
 875            return trace
 876        else: #Does not use the list index format, so computing commutators is slower
 877            maxsize = 0
 878            #Prepares two lists: One for v matching dense coefficients with indices in g, One for H matching coefficients to indeices
 879            resV = [self.vcoefs,self.cartan.h]
 880            resH = [self.hamiltonian.HCoefs, self.hamiltonian.HTuples]
 881
 882            for i in range(len(thetas1)-1,index,-1):
 883                resV = self.adj_action(thetas1[i],self.cartan.k[i],resV[0],resV[1])
 884
 885            
 886            #add each exp(thetas2*k2) to the list in reverse order and negative coefficients
 887            for i in range(index):
 888                resH = self.adj_action(-thetas2[i],self.cartan.k[i],resH[0],resH[1])
 889
 890            #create identity matrix for this dimensions
 891            I = (0,)*self.hamiltonian.sites
 892            
 893            
 894            resV = self.multiplyLinCombRound([1],[I],resV[0],resV[1],self.accuracy)  
 895            
 896            if index >= 0:
 897                resV = self.multiplyLinCombRound([math.cos(thetas1[index]),1j*math.sin(thetas1[index])],[I,self.cartan.k[index]],resV[0],resV[1],self.accuracy)    
 898
 899                resV = self.multiplyLinCombRound(resV[0],resV[1],[math.cos(thetas2[index]),-1j*math.sin(thetas2[index])],[I,self.cartan.k[index]],self.accuracy)    
 900
 901                    
 902            #get trace of v*H
 903            trace = 0
 904            for i in range(len(resV[0])):
 905                for j in range(len(resH[0])):
 906                    if resV[1][i] == resH[1][j]:
 907                        trace = trace + resV[0][i]*resH[0][j]
 908            
 909            return trace
 910    def CostFunction(self, thetas):
 911        '''
 912        returns Tr(exp(thetas‚Ä¢k)‚Ä¢v‚Ä¢exp(-thetas‚Ä¢k)‚Ä¢H)
 913        '''

 920    def gradCostFunction(self, thetas):
 921        '''
 922        returns gradient of funky. Order of derivatives is the order of the parameters thetas.
 923        '''
 924        
 925        res = np.zeros(len(thetas))
 926        
 927        for i in range(len(thetas)):
 928            thetascopy = thetas.copy()
 929            thetascopy[i] = thetascopy[i]+math.pi/2
 930            
 931            diff = self.generalCostFunction(thetascopy,thetas, i) + self.generalCostFunction(thetas,thetascopy,i)
 932            
 933            res[i] = diff.real
 934            
 935        return res

 937    def adj_action(self,theta,k,coefs,tuples): 
 938        '''Computes Ad<sub>k</sub>(m) = e<sup>i‚Ä¢theta</sup>(coefs ‚Ä¢ tuples)e<sup>-i‚Ä¢theta</sup>
 939        Also known as the Adjoint Representation
 940
 941        Args:
 942            theta (float): A single value, the coeffient of the k PauilString
 943            k (Tuple): A (PauliString)
 944            coefs (List of floats, can be complex): The coefficients indexed in order of the elements in tuples
 945            tuples (List of tuples): A List of (PauliStrings)
 946        
 947        Returns:
 948            The Algebraic element in m which is the result of the Adjoint Action (Representation)
 949        '''
 950        if self.useCommTables:
 951            result = [[],[]]
 952            
 953            for i in range(len(coefs)): #Generally, this is applied to v, an element in h and in m. Iterates over the elements in m
 954                m = tuples[i] #m is the index of some m element
 955                c = coefs[i] #c is the associate index
 956            
 957                res = [[c],[m]] #Just establishes the normal coefficient + tupleIndex pair
 958                comm = self.commutatePauliString(1,k,c/2,m) #Computes the commutator of the m currently in the loopand input k element,
 959                if comm[0] != 0:
 960                    res = [[c*math.cos(2*theta),1j*math.sin(2*theta)*comm[0]],[m,comm[1]]]  #If they do not commute, computes ?? (The exponential?)
 961                    
 962                for q in range(len(res[0])):
 963                    flag = 0
 964                    for j in range(len(result[0])):
 965                        if res[1][q] == result[1][j]:
 966                            result[0][j] = result[0][j] + res[0][q]
 967                            flag = 1
 968                            break
 969                    if flag == 0:
 970                        result[0].append(res[0][q])
 971                        result[1].append(res[1][q])
 972                            
 973            return result
 974        else:
 975
 976            result = [[],[]]
 977            
 978            for i in range(len(coefs)): #Generally, this is applied to v, an element in h and in m. Iterates over the elements in m
 979                m = tuples[i] #m is the index of some m element
 980                c = coefs[i] #c is the associate index
 981            
 982                res = [[c],[m]] #Just establishes the normal coefficient + tupleIndex pair
 983                comm = self.commutatePauliString(1,k,c/2,m) #Computes the commutator of the m currently in the loopand input k element,
 984                if comm[0] != 0:
 985                    res = [[c*math.cos(2*theta),1j*math.sin(2*theta)*comm[0]],[m,comm[1]]]  #If they do not commute, computes ?? (The exponential?)
 986                    
 987                for q in range(len(res[0])):
 988                    flag = 0
 989                    for j in range(len(result[0])):
 990                        if res[1][q] == result[1][j]:
 991                            result[0][j] = result[0][j] + res[0][q]
 992                            flag = 1
 993                            break
 994                    if flag == 0:
 995                        result[0].append(res[0][q])
 996                        result[1].append(res[1][q])
 997                            
 998            return result

1000    def sethVecFromk(self):
1001        '''
1002        Returns h = exp(-thetas‚Ä¢k)‚Ä¢H‚Ä¢exp(thetas‚Ä¢k)
1003
1004        Defines hErrorTuples and hErrorCoefs, which are the exact result of the adjoint representation. The result is in m, not in h, though it is mostly in h. 
1005
1006        hCoefs and hTuples are the results stripped of the components in m
1007        '''
1008
1009        I = (0,)*self.hamiltonian.sites
1010        
1011        res = [self.hamiltonian.HCoefs, self.hamiltonian.HTuples]
1012        
1013        #calculate exp(+...)*H*exp(-...)
1014        for i in range(len(self.kCoefs)):
1015            res = self.adj_action(-self.kCoefs[i],self.cartan.k[i],res[0],res[1])
1016        #Strips off error terms that ended up in m
1017
1018        self.hErrorTuples = res[1]
1019        self.hErrorCoefs = res[0]
1020
1021        self.hCoefs = []
1022        for w in self.cartan.h:
1023            hflag = 0
1024            for u in range(len(self.hErrorTuples)):
1025                if w == self.hErrorTuples[u]:
1026                    self.hCoefs.append(self.hErrorCoefs[u])
1027                    hflag = 1
1028                    break
1029            if hflag == 0:
1030                self.hCoefs.append(0)
1031        self.hTuples = self.cartan.h

1033    def errorhVec(self):
1034        '''Gets the norm square of the part in hcoefs‚Ä¢htuples that is orthogonal to Cartan subalgebra h.
1035        '''
1036        result = 0
1037        
1038        for i in range(len(self.hErrorCoefs)):
1039            
1040            term = self.hErrorTuples[i]
1041            flag = 0
1042            for j in range(self.lenh):
1043                if term == self.hTuples[j]:
1044                    flag = 1
1045                    break
1046            if flag == 0:
1047                result = result + abs(self.hErrorCoefs[i])**2
1048                
1049        return result

1051    def multiplyLinComb(self,A,tuplesA,B,tuplesB):
1052        '''
1053        Returns multiplication of two linear combinations of Pauli terms 
1054        '''
1055
1056        a = len(A)
1057        b = len(B)
1058        
1059        C = []
1060        tuplesC = []
1061        csize = 0
1062        
1063        for i in range(a):
1064            for j in range(b):
1065                term = self.multiplyPauliString(A[i],tuplesA[i],B[j],tuplesB[j])
1066                flag = 0
1067                for k in range(csize):
1068                    if tuplesC[k]==term[1]:
1069                        flag = 1
1070                        C[k] = C[k]+term[0]
1071                if flag == 0:
1072                    C.append(term[0])
1073                    tuplesC.append(term[1])
1074                    csize = csize + 1
1075        
1076        return C, tuplesC

1078    def multiplyPauliString(self,a,tupleA,b,tupleB):
1079        """Computes the multiplication of two Pauli Strings representated as a tuple
1080
1081        Args:
1082            a (np.complex128): 
1083                The coefficient of the first Pauli String term
1084            tupleA (Tuple or index in g):
1085                tuple represenation of the first Pauli String
1086            b (np.complex128):
1087                The coefficient of the second Pauli String term
1088            tupleB (Tuple or index in g): 
1089                tuple represenation of the second Pauli String
1090
1091        Returns:
1092            c (np.complex128):
1093                The coefficient of the result a‚Ä¢TupleA . b‚Ä¢TupleB = c‚Ä¢TupleC, where c (the sign of the product of Paulis ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ b)
1094            tupleC (tuple) :
1095                the elementwise product of the PauliString, ignoring coefficients. 
1096        """
1097        if type(tupleA) != tuple:
1098            tupleA = self.cartan.g[int(tupleA)]
1099        if type(tupleB) != tuple:
1100            tupleB = self.cartan.g[int(tupleB)]
1101            
1102        sites = len(tupleA)
1103        #builds up the result Tuple C
1104        tupleC = ()
1105        sign = 1 # sign(a.b)
1106        
1107        #Iterate elementwise over the tuple
1108        for i in range(sites):
1109            #tupleC is the tuple represenation of the result of the commutator 
1110            tupleC += (((tupleA[i] + tupleB[i]*RULES[tupleA[i]]) % 4),)
1111            #Complex integer product of all the elementwise multiplications
1112            sign = sign * SIGN_RULES[tupleA[i]][tupleB[i]]
1113            
1114        c = a * b * sign
1115        return c, tupleC  
1116    
1117    def commutatePauliString(self,a,tupleA,b,tupleB):
1118        """Computes the commutator of two Pauli Strings representated as a tuple
1119
1120        Args:
1121            a (np.complex128): 
1122                The coefficient of the first Pauli String term
1123            tupleA (Tuple, integer): 
1124                tuple represenation of the first Pauli String, or the index in the commutator table
1125            b (np.complex128): 
1126                The coefficient of the second Pauli String term
1127            tupleB (tuple, int): 
1128                tuple represenation of the second Pauli String, or the index in the commutator table
1129        
1130        Returns:
1131            c (np.complex128):
1132                The coefficient of the result [a‚Ä¢TupleA,b‚Ä¢TupleB] = c‚Ä¢TupleC, where c is the Structure Constant ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ b.
1133            
1134            tupleC (tuple): 
1135                the elementwise commutator of the PauliString, ignoring coefficients. 
1136        """
1137        
1138        if type(tupleA)==tuple:
1139        
1140            sites = len(tupleA)
1141            #builds up the result Tuple C
1142            tupleC = ()
1143
1144            signForward = 1 # sign(a.b)
1145            signBackward = 1 # sign(b.a) 
1146
1147
1148            #Iterate elementwise over the tuple
1149            for i in range(sites):
1150                #tupleC is the tuple represenation of the result of the commutator 
1151                tupleC += (((tupleA[i] + tupleB[i]*RULES[tupleA[i]]) % 4),)
1152                #Complex integer product of all the elementwise multiplications going forward
1153                signForward = signForward * SIGN_RULES[tupleA[i]][tupleB[i]]
1154                #Complex integer product of all the elementwise multiplications going backward
1155                signBackward = signBackward * SIGN_RULES[tupleB[i]][tupleA[i]]
1156
1157            #Checks the signs forward and backwards. If they are the same, it commutes
1158            if signForward == signBackward:
1159                return (0,tupleC)
1160            else:
1161                c = a * b * 2*signForward
1162                return c, tupleC
1163        
1164        else:
1165            return (a*b*self.comm_coefs[int(tupleA)][int(tupleB)]), self.comm_table[int(tupleA)][int(tupleB)] 
1166    
1167    def multiplyLinCombRound(self,A,tuplesA,B,tuplesB, accur):
1168        '''
1169        Returns multiplication of two linear combinations of Pauli terms, and rounds things that are smaller than accur to zero. 
1170        '''
1171
1172        a = len(A)
1173        b = len(B)
1174        
1175        C = []
1176        tuplesC = []
1177        csize = 0
1178        
1179        for i in range(a):
1180            for j in range(b):
1181                term = self.multiplyPauliString(A[i],tuplesA[i],B[j],tuplesB[j])
1182                flag = 0
1183                for k in range(csize):
1184                    if tuplesC[k]==term[1]:
1185                        flag = 1
1186                        C[k] = C[k]+term[0]
1187                if (flag == 0) & (abs(term[0])>accur):
1188                    C.append(term[0])
1189                    tuplesC.append(term[1])
1190                    csize = csize + 1
1191        
1192        return C, tuplesC

From a Cartan Decomposition, runs the optimizer to find the appropriate parameters for a circuit

Warning: Very long runtime for more than 8ish qubits

Authors:

  • Thomas Steckmann
  • Efekan Kokcu
FindParameters( cartan, saveFileName=None, loadfileName=None, optimizerMethod='BFGS', accuracy=1e-05, initialGuess=None, steps=5000, useCommTables=True) 
652    def __init__(self, cartan, saveFileName = None, loadfileName=None, optimizerMethod='BFGS', accuracy=1e-5, initialGuess=None, steps = 5000, useCommTables=True):
653        """
654        Initializing a FindParameters class automatically runs the optimizer over the Cartan decomposition and provided Hamiltonian
655        
656        If saveFileName is provided, verifies file location before proceeding, and saves the output as a csv
657        If loadFileName is provided, does not run the optimizer and instead reads data from the provided file
658
659        TODO:
660            * Write Load file functions
661        
662        Args:
663            cartan (Obj Cartan): The Cartan object containing the k,h, and Hamiltonian information
664            saveFileName (String, default=None): path to save the output. Do not include an extension ('csv' or 'txt')
665            loadFileName (String, default=None): path to a csv containing previous optimizer results. Do not add .csv or .txt
666            optimizer (String, default='BFGS'): The Scipy optimizer to use. Easy to add new ones, but must be done manually
667                
668                Options: 
669                    * `'BFGS'` : Uses Gradient
670                    * `'Powel'`: Does not use Gradient
671            accuracy (float, default=1e-5): Optimizer convergence Criteria
672            initialGuess (List of values): Allows the user to specify the inital guess for k. Must be correct, no input checking is currently implemented
673            steps (int): The maximum number of optimization steps before termination
674        
675        Returns:
676            * Progress updates and runtime predictions
677            * prints the results of the optimization
678        """
679        #Initialize Values
680        self.cartan = cartan #Extracts the hamiltonian object
681        self.hamiltonian = self.cartan.hamiltonian #Extracts the hamiltonain objects
682        self.useCommTables = useCommTables
683        self.optimizerMethod = optimizerMethod
684        self.accuracy = accuracy
685        self.lenK = len(self.cartan.k)
686        self.lenh = len(self.cartan.h)
687        self.steps = steps
688        #Begin Optimizer
689        if loadfileName is not None: #If able to, loads prior results
690            #with open(loadfileName + '.csv', "r") as f:
691            #    csv_reader = csv.reader(csv_file, delimiter=',')
692            raise Exception('Unable to continue, file loading is not implemented')
693        elif self.lenK == 0: #Specific exception handling to prevent breaking on commuting Hamiltonians 
694            self.hCoefs = self.hamiltonian.HCoefs
695            #self.hTuples = self.hamiltonian.HTuples
696            self.kCoefs = []
697        else:   
698            if saveFileName is not None:
699                if not os.access(saveFileName, os.W_OK): #Verifies write permission
700                    raise Exception('Save File location does not have write access. Aborting Optimization.')
701                self.saveFileName = saveFileName
702            
703            #Generating reused values before begining the optimizer loop
704            if useCommTables == True: #Faster, but only works for a complete algebra
705                self.setCommutatorTables() #Sets values for a look-up table for the commutators
706                self.generateIndexLists()
707            #Generates coefficients for v, a dense element in the h algebra
708            pi = np.pi
709            self.vcoefs = [1]
710            for i in range(len(self.cartan.h)-1):
711                term = pi*self.vcoefs[i]
712                while term > 1:
713                    term = term-1
714                self.vcoefs.append(term)
715            
716
717            
718            #If specified, defines an inital guess. If not, sets it to all zeros
719            if initialGuess is not None:
720                self.initialGuess = initialGuess
721            else:
722                self.initialGuess = initialGuess = np.zeros(len(self.cartan.k))
723            
724            #Calls the function that contains the optimizer loop
725            total_time = time.time()
726            self.optimizerOutput = self.optimize()
727            timepassed = time.time() - total_time
728            print('--- ' + str(timepassed) +  ' seconds ---')
729
730            self.sethVecFromk()
731            self.error = self.errorhVec()
732
733            print('Optimization Error:')
734            print(self.error)
735
736            if saveFileName is not None:
737                self.saveKH()

def setCommutatorTables(self): 
739    def setCommutatorTables(self):
740        """ 
741        Generates commutator look-up tables for the commutators of different elements
742
743        Important: g must be ordered as k + h + (the rest of m). Does not work without this ordering
744        """
745        
746        k_tuples = self.cartan.k.copy()
747        h_tuples = self.cartan.h.copy()
748        m_tuples = self.cartan.m.copy()
749        
750        index = 0
751        
752        while index < len(m_tuples):
753            flag = 0
754            for i in range(len(h_tuples)):
755                if m_tuples[index] == h_tuples[i]:
756                    flag = 1
757                    m_tuples.pop(index)
758                    break
759            if flag == 0:
760                index = index + 1
761        
762        g_tuples = k_tuples + h_tuples + m_tuples
763        
764        self.comm_table = np.zeros((len(g_tuples),len(g_tuples)))
765        self.comm_coefs = np.zeros((len(g_tuples),len(g_tuples)),dtype=np.complex_)
766        
767        for i in range(len(g_tuples)):
768            for j in range(len(g_tuples)):
769                res = self.commutatePauliString(1,g_tuples[i],1,g_tuples[j])
770                
771                self.comm_coefs[i][j] = res[0]
772                
773                if res[0]==0:
774                    self.comm_table[i][j]=0
775                else:
776                    for q in range(len(g_tuples)):
777                        if res[1] == g_tuples[q]:
778                            self.comm_table[i][j] = q

Generates commutator look-up tables for the commutators of different elements

def generateIndexLists(self): 
780    def generateIndexLists(self):
781        """Generates a lists for H, h, and k using indices in g instead of as lists of Tuples"""
782
783        #Computes the indices of each of the k elements in the g list                   
784        self.kElementIndices = []
785        for i in range(len(self.cartan.k)):
786            for j in range(len(self.cartan.g)):
787                if self.cartan.k[i] == self.cartan.g[j]:
788                    self.kElementIndices.append(j)
789                    break  
790
791        #computes the indicies of each of the Ham elements in the g list
792        self.HElementIndices = [] 
793        Htuples = self.hamiltonian.HTuples
794        for i in range(len(Htuples)):
795            for j in range(len(self.cartan.g)):
796                if self.cartan.g[j]==Htuples[i]:
797                    self.HElementIndices.append(j)
798                    break
799        
800        #Computes the indices of the of the h elements in the g list:
801        self.hElementIndices = [] 
802        htuples = self.cartan.h
803        for i in range(len(htuples)):
804            for j in range(len(self.cartan.g)):
805                if self.cartan.g[j]==htuples[i]:
806                    self.hElementIndices.append(j)
807                    break

Generates a lists for H, h, and k using indices in g instead of as lists of Tuples

def optimize(self): 
809    def optimize(self):
810        """
811        Chooses between methods of optimization. Current options are 'BFGS' and 'Powell' from scipy.optimize
812
813        Sets the attribute kCoefs, which are the results of the optimizer
814
815        Returns: 
816            The object returned by the Scipy Optimizer. Contains information about the minimum, parameters, and a few other things
817        """
818        initialGuess = self.initialGuess
819        if self.optimizerMethod == 'BFGS':
820            optimiumReturn = scipy.optimize.minimize(self.CostFunction,initialGuess, method='BFGS', jac = self.gradCostFunction,options={'disp':True, 'gtol':self.accuracy, 'maxiter':self.steps})
821        elif self.optimizerMethod == 'Powell':
822            optimiumReturn = scipy.optimize.minimize(self.CostFunction,initialGuess, method='Powell',options={'disp':True, 'ftol':self.accuracy, 'maxiter':self.steps})
823        self.kCoefs = optimiumReturn.x
824        return optimiumReturn

def gradCostFunction(self, thetas): 
920    def gradCostFunction(self, thetas):
921        '''
922        returns gradient of funky. Order of derivatives is the order of the parameters thetas.
923        '''
924        
925        res = np.zeros(len(thetas))
926        
927        for i in range(len(thetas)):
928            thetascopy = thetas.copy()
929            thetascopy[i] = thetascopy[i]+math.pi/2
930            
931            diff = self.generalCostFunction(thetascopy,thetas, i) + self.generalCostFunction(thetas,thetascopy,i)
932            
933            res[i] = diff.real
934            
935        return res

def adj_action(self, theta, k, coefs, tuples): 
937    def adj_action(self,theta,k,coefs,tuples): 
938        '''Computes Ad<sub>k</sub>(m) = e<sup>i‚Ä¢theta</sup>(coefs ‚Ä¢ tuples)e<sup>-i‚Ä¢theta</sup>
939        Also known as the Adjoint Representation
940
941        Args:
942            theta (float): A single value, the coeffient of the k PauilString
943            k (Tuple): A (PauliString)
944            coefs (List of floats, can be complex): The coefficients indexed in order of the elements in tuples
945            tuples (List of tuples): A List of (PauliStrings)
946        
947        Returns:
948            The Algebraic element in m which is the result of the Adjoint Action (Representation)
949        '''
950        if self.useCommTables:
951            result = [[],[]]
952            
953            for i in range(len(coefs)): #Generally, this is applied to v, an element in h and in m. Iterates over the elements in m
954                m = tuples[i] #m is the index of some m element
955                c = coefs[i] #c is the associate index
956            
957                res = [[c],[m]] #Just establishes the normal coefficient + tupleIndex pair
958                comm = self.commutatePauliString(1,k,c/2,m) #Computes the commutator of the m currently in the loopand input k element,
959                if comm[0] != 0:
960                    res = [[c*math.cos(2*theta),1j*math.sin(2*theta)*comm[0]],[m,comm[1]]]  #If they do not commute, computes ?? (The exponential?)
961                    
962                for q in range(len(res[0])):
963                    flag = 0
964                    for j in range(len(result[0])):
965                        if res[1][q] == result[1][j]:
966                            result[0][j] = result[0][j] + res[0][q]
967                            flag = 1
968                            break
969                    if flag == 0:
970                        result[0].append(res[0][q])
971                        result[1].append(res[1][q])
972                            
973            return result
974        else:
975
976            result = [[],[]]
977            
978            for i in range(len(coefs)): #Generally, this is applied to v, an element in h and in m. Iterates over the elements in m
979                m = tuples[i] #m is the index of some m element
980                c = coefs[i] #c is the associate index
981            
982                res = [[c],[m]] #Just establishes the normal coefficient + tupleIndex pair
983                comm = self.commutatePauliString(1,k,c/2,m) #Computes the commutator of the m currently in the loopand input k element,
984                if comm[0] != 0:
985                    res = [[c*math.cos(2*theta),1j*math.sin(2*theta)*comm[0]],[m,comm[1]]]  #If they do not commute, computes ?? (The exponential?)
986                    
987                for q in range(len(res[0])):
988                    flag = 0
989                    for j in range(len(result[0])):
990                        if res[1][q] == result[1][j]:
991                            result[0][j] = result[0][j] + res[0][q]
992                            flag = 1
993                            break
994                    if flag == 0:
995                        result[0].append(res[0][q])
996                        result[1].append(res[1][q])
997                            
998            return result

def multiplyPauliString(self, a, tupleA, b, tupleB): 
1078    def multiplyPauliString(self,a,tupleA,b,tupleB):
1079        """Computes the multiplication of two Pauli Strings representated as a tuple
1080
1081        Args:
1082            a (np.complex128): 
1083                The coefficient of the first Pauli String term
1084            tupleA (Tuple or index in g):
1085                tuple represenation of the first Pauli String
1086            b (np.complex128):
1087                The coefficient of the second Pauli String term
1088            tupleB (Tuple or index in g): 
1089                tuple represenation of the second Pauli String
1090
1091        Returns:
1092            c (np.complex128):
1093                The coefficient of the result a‚Ä¢TupleA . b‚Ä¢TupleB = c‚Ä¢TupleC, where c (the sign of the product of Paulis ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ b)
1094            tupleC (tuple) :
1095                the elementwise product of the PauliString, ignoring coefficients. 
1096        """
1097        if type(tupleA) != tuple:
1098            tupleA = self.cartan.g[int(tupleA)]
1099        if type(tupleB) != tuple:
1100            tupleB = self.cartan.g[int(tupleB)]
1101            
1102        sites = len(tupleA)
1103        #builds up the result Tuple C
1104        tupleC = ()
1105        sign = 1 # sign(a.b)
1106        
1107        #Iterate elementwise over the tuple
1108        for i in range(sites):
1109            #tupleC is the tuple represenation of the result of the commutator 
1110            tupleC += (((tupleA[i] + tupleB[i]*RULES[tupleA[i]]) % 4),)
1111            #Complex integer product of all the elementwise multiplications
1112            sign = sign * SIGN_RULES[tupleA[i]][tupleB[i]]
1113            
1114        c = a * b * sign
1115        return c, tupleC

Computes the multiplication of two Pauli Strings representated as a tuple

  • tupleA (Tuple or index in g): tuple represenation of the first Pauli String
  • b (np.complex128): The coefficient of the second Pauli String term
  • tupleB (Tuple or index in g): tuple represenation of the second Pauli String
Returns

c (np.complex128): The coefficient of the result a‚Ä¢TupleA . b‚Ä¢TupleB = c‚Ä¢TupleC, where c (the sign of the product of Paulis ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ b) tupleC (tuple) : the elementwise product of the PauliString, ignoring coefficients.

def commutatePauliString(self, a, tupleA, b, tupleB): 
1117    def commutatePauliString(self,a,tupleA,b,tupleB):
1118        """Computes the commutator of two Pauli Strings representated as a tuple
1119
1120        Args:
1121            a (np.complex128): 
1122                The coefficient of the first Pauli String term
1123            tupleA (Tuple, integer): 
1124                tuple represenation of the first Pauli String, or the index in the commutator table
1125            b (np.complex128): 
1126                The coefficient of the second Pauli String term
1127            tupleB (tuple, int): 
1128                tuple represenation of the second Pauli String, or the index in the commutator table
1129        
1130        Returns:
1131            c (np.complex128):
1132                The coefficient of the result [a‚Ä¢TupleA,b‚Ä¢TupleB] = c‚Ä¢TupleC, where c is the Structure Constant ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ b.
1133            
1134            tupleC (tuple): 
1135                the elementwise commutator of the PauliString, ignoring coefficients. 
1136        """
1137        
1138        if type(tupleA)==tuple:
1139        
1140            sites = len(tupleA)
1141            #builds up the result Tuple C
1142            tupleC = ()
1143
1144            signForward = 1 # sign(a.b)
1145            signBackward = 1 # sign(b.a) 
1146
1147
1148            #Iterate elementwise over the tuple
1149            for i in range(sites):
1150                #tupleC is the tuple represenation of the result of the commutator 
1151                tupleC += (((tupleA[i] + tupleB[i]*RULES[tupleA[i]]) % 4),)
1152                #Complex integer product of all the elementwise multiplications going forward
1153                signForward = signForward * SIGN_RULES[tupleA[i]][tupleB[i]]
1154                #Complex integer product of all the elementwise multiplications going backward
1155                signBackward = signBackward * SIGN_RULES[tupleB[i]][tupleA[i]]
1156
1157            #Checks the signs forward and backwards. If they are the same, it commutes
1158            if signForward == signBackward:
1159                return (0,tupleC)
1160            else:
1161                c = a * b * 2*signForward
1162                return c, tupleC
1163        
1164        else:
1165            return (a*b*self.comm_coefs[int(tupleA)][int(tupleB)]), self.comm_table[int(tupleA)][int(tupleB)]

  • tupleA (Tuple, integer): tuple represenation of the first Pauli String, or the index in the commutator table
  • b (np.complex128): The coefficient of the second Pauli String term
  • tupleB (tuple, int): tuple represenation of the second Pauli String, or the index in the commutator table
Returns

c (np.complex128): The coefficient of the result [a‚Ä¢TupleA,b‚Ä¢TupleB] = c‚Ä¢TupleC, where c is the Structure Constant ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ b.

tupleC (tuple): the elementwise commutator of the PauliString, ignoring coefficients.
